title: What is the best Doors album? - Quora

response.answer_text: Tough question. Usually, when it comes to choosing a band’s best or worst album, I can easily do so without hesitation, but The Doors, as always, are a bit different… The easy choice (the one the casual fan might make) would be to immediately point at “The one with the singles on it”, i.e., their debut. And I wouldn’t be able to find any solid argument against that choice because it is a magnificent album. But as I say, that’s the easy choice; the one that requires no thought at all.And considering how much of the band’s depth can be found in the so called“deep cuts” on their albums; the songs that were never released as singles at all, but instead left to gather dust among their more illustrious brothers and sisters? It’s on those tracks that The Doors were more free to express themselves and take risks. And it would be a great disservice to simply focus on the famous hits we’ve all heard on the radio and in films, etc, while ignoring the many strange and wonderful gems hidden away and waiting to be discovered or rediscovered. I personally don’t know which the best Doors album is. I have an idea. In fact, I have at least two or three ideas! But to make this as fair as possible, I will have to go through each and every Doors album and score each and every song before adding it all up and then draw conclusions and shit. Oh, I will NOT include “Other Voices” or “Full Circle” since they were released posthumously after Morrison’s death and are not proper band albums, in my opinion.But I WILL include “An American Prayer” because, hey, it does have Morrison on it. Let’s break on through, shall we? The Doors  Break On Through (to the Other Side) - Great, classic rocker. Hard vocals. 5/5Soul Kitchen - Generic 60’s keyboards and guitar, but the vocals save it. 4/5The Crystal Ship - Beautiful, mellow tune. Nice piano work as well. 4/5Twentieth Century Fox - Catchy little tune. Might’ve made an OK single. 3,5/5Alabama Song (Whisky Bar) - OK. I prefer Bowie’s demented version. 2,5/5Light My Fire - Famous riff. Great song The ultimate 60’s psych jam. 5/5Back Door Man - Stomping blues number about anal sex. 3/5I Looked at You - Silly pop song. Has some nice playing on it. 3/5End of the Night - The “Twin Peaks” song. Nocturnal and weird. 4/5Take It as It Comes - Sounds like a mishmash of all the songs so far. 3/5The End - Out of nowhere, a monumental masterpiece for the ages. 5/5Song Score: 42/55 Percentage Score: 76% Lizard Skins: 4/5 Strange Days  Strange Days - Not so strange, except for the vocal effect. 3/5You’re Lost Little Girl - A real hidden gem, this one. 4/5Love Me Two Times - Great song with furious harpsichord solo! 5/5Unhappy Girl - Remove the carnival sounds and this is pretty meh. 3/5Horse Latitudes - Morrison screams like a prophet over sound effects. 2/5Moonlight Drive - Just a blues, really. But has a nice guitar solo. 4/5People Are Strange - Classic anthem for the alienated and lonely. 5/5My Eyes Have Seen You - Would make a pretty good punk rock song. 3/5I Can’t See Your Face in My Mind - Nothing special. Nice singing. 2/5When the Music’s Over - “The End -part 2”? Well, it wants to be… 4/5Song Score: 35/50 Percentage Score: 70% Lizard Skins: 3,5/5 Waiting for the Sun  Hello, I Love You - Rips off the Kinks’ “All Day and All of the Night”. 3/5Love Street - Pretty abysmal love song. What the fuck? 2/5Not to Touch the Earth - Pumping rock song that goes nowhere. 3/5Summer’s Almost Gone - So is the band’s energy. Awful. 2/5Wintertime Love - Sadly, winter’s even worse… 2/5The Unknown Soldier - The band’s worst single. Not terrible, though. 3/5Spanish Caravan - Bach-ish folk tune with nice pseudo-flamenco guitar. 4/5My Wild Love - Morrison sings a cappella with a choir of drunks. 2/5We Could Be So Good Together - If we could only write a good song. 2/5Yes, the River Knows - Easy listening at its worst. Embarrassing. 2/5Five to One - Great stomper. No one gets out alive, indeed. 4/5Song Score: 29/55 Percentage Score: 53% Lizard Skins: 2,5/5 The Soft Parade  Tell All the People - Beautiful soft pop. Could be a Carpenters track. 4/5Touch Me - Superb pop crooner with some tasty brass and jazz sax. 5/5Shaman’s Blues - Cool title. Nice fuzz guitar. Not much of a song. 3/5Do It - This has a good guitar riff, but the song is too repetitive. 3/5Easy Ride - Someone’s listened to Dylan’s trio of electric albums… 2/5Wild Child - Decent riff and slide guitar and……nothing else. 2/5Runnin’ Blue - This mixes every style of music known to man. 2/5Wishful Sinful - “Mumbling and String” could’ve been the title. 2/5The Soft Parade - The title track’s supposed to be good, isn’t it? 2/5Song Score: 25/45 Percentage Score: 56% Lizard Skins: 3/5 Morrison Hotel  Roadhouse Blues - Dirty bar blues. Released only as a B-side!!! 4/5Waiting for the Sun - Better than anything on its eponymous album. 4/5You Make Me Real - Even simple blues is great when it rocks this hard. 4/5Peace Frog - The Doors quite possibly invent funk. And it’s good. 5/5Blue Sunday - Gorgeous ballad. One of Morrison’s best performances. 5/5Ship of Fools - Swinging little rocker. Won’t harm anyone. 3/5Land Ho! - The boys go crazy for some shore whores. Nice shuffle. 4/5The Spy - Witty blues. Nothing special but it sounds damn good. 4/5Queen of the Highway - Bit of a filler track. But nice playing. 3/5Indian Summer - Lounge version of “The End” I guess. 3/5Maggie M’Gill - Pretty hard-hitting blues jam. 3/5Song Score: 42/55 Percentage Score: 76% Lizard Skins: 4/5 L.A. Woman  The Changeling - Great, driving groove, but no melody to speak of. 3/5Love Her Madly - Average pop song. Nice tack piano, though. 3/5Been Down So Long - Pissed off and boring. Quite a feat! 2/5Car Hiss by My Window - The most boring blues you’ll ever hear. 2/5L.A. Woman - Bittersweet love letter to the City of Angels. SUPERB. 5/5L’America - Down to the psycho circus we march. OK, I guess. 3/5Hyacinth House - Beautiful and depressed. This is rather good. 4/5Crawling King Snake - Slow 12-bar blues. Ever so boring. 2/5The WASP (Texas Radio and the Big Beat) - Unusually complex. Nice. 4/5Riders on the Storm - The ultimate late-night, spooky driving song. 5/5Song Score: 31/50 Percentage Score: 62% Lizard Skins: 3/5 An American Prayer  Awake - Live recording of Morrison screaming “Wake up!”. 1/5Ghost Song - Poetry spoken over a damn funky track. 4/5Dawn’s Highway - Jim babbles about an accident he saw as a kid. 2/5Newborn Awakening - Basically “Peace Frog” with new lyrics. 3/5To Come of Age - Soldiers marching as Jim gets a hard-on, on a bus. 1/5Black Polished Chrome - Upbeat blues. More poetry. Good, but short. 3/5Latino Chrome - Jim reads poetry over a tasteful Latino backing. 3/5Angels and Sailors - More poetry mixed with Robert Johnson-type blues. 2/5Stoned Immaculate - The WASP revisited. We’ve heard this before. 1/5The Movie - Jim reads poetry over backwards-playing bell sounds. 1/5Curses, Invocations - Yet more poetry. Over smooth jazz this time. 3/5American Night - Jim mumbles. A piano plays a chord. 1/5Roadhouse Blues - Great live version. Arguably superior. 4/5The World on Fire - Sounds of a rioting audience. More poetry. 1/5Lament - Jim wrote this about his……cock. Yeah… 2/5The Hitchhiker - Jim tells a boring story. “Riders on the Storm” plays. 1/5An American Prayer - “Ghost Song” with a different poem. WTF? 2/5Hour for Magic - Poetry read over “The End”. 1/5Freedom Exists - 20-second poem. Shit. 1/5A Feast of Friends - Another fucking poem. But the music is nice. 3/5Babylon Fading - More poetry over pretty good sound effects. 2/5Bird of Prey - A cappella song. Sampled by Fatboy Slim. Was a top 10 hit. 2/5The Ghost Song - The fucking “Ghost Song” is repeated AGAIN! 2/5Song Score: 46/115 Percentage Score: 40% Lizard Skins: 2/5 RESULTOoooh, we have a tie! Both “The Doors” and “Morrison Hotel” have scored 4/5.Furthermore, they both have the same percentage score!That doesn’t happen every day. Hmm…what to do? How do we settle this? Well, their debut album has 3 top score songs whereas “Morrison Hotel” only has 2. A bit of an anticlimactic finale, perhaps, but I’m going to have to give the title ofBest Doors Album to their debut, “The Doors”, simply because it has slightly more classic songs on it. But “Morrison Hotel” is actually a stronger and more consistent album, in my opinion. The safe choice is the winner. The one that all the casual fans know. How boring.

In retrospect, it's easy to conclude the Doors were way ahead of their time, enjoying critical and popular acclaim years after the death of Jim Morrison and the cult following that continues to this day. The first eponymous album captures the group in essence, ranging from the scary-circus theme that drove 'Light My Fire’ to the Oedipal bombastic climax, ‘The End'. Critically and commercially, 'Strange Days' not only expanded the Doors' mystique, but improved on it with the singles 'People Are Strange’ and 'Love Me Two Times’, as well as another opus, 'When The Music's Over'. The subsequent albums continued the audial head trip, but by then the message (and Morrison's drug-induced equilibrium) began to stumble, despite occasional beams of brilliance.
